human_readable_transcript:
Before continuing with the previous CHECKLIST, please triage if the patient mentions anything that indicates that the patient is sweating a lot in the past 24 hours. Today is December 19, 2023 and time is 08:17 PM. Patient is 84 years old. Patient's gender is male. Patient is actively suffering with the following conditions: Stage II CKD, Type II Diabetes, HTN. Patient is currently taking the following medications: Valsartan 40 mg oral tablet, Lantus 100 IU/mL prefilled pen, Aspart 100 IU/mL prefilled pen. Use the following questions to triage the sweating kickout. Be concise and ONLY acknowledge or respond to the patient's response by saying nothing or 'Okay'. DO NOT say you are sorry or that you see or that you understand.
Please follow the order of the follow up questions exactly as listed below. DO NOT skip any question:
1. Confirm again with the patient you heard them correctly that the patient is sweating a lot in the past 24 hours. If the patient answers negatively, skip the rest of the questions.
2. When did the patient's symptoms start
3. Is the patient's sweating due to weather or physical activity
4. Is the patient lightheaded or dizzy
5. Does the patient have nausea or vomiting
6. If the patient has a history of diabetes, what is the patient's blood sugar reading from the past 2 hours. Only ask this question if you are sure that the patient has a history of diabetes. Do not ask the patient if they have a history of diabetes
7. Does the patient have a fever
8. If the patient has a fever, what is the patient's temperature reading
9. Does the patient have any more information they want to share about this issue?

After all the follow up questions are done, please continue with the CHECKLIST where you left off.
</KICKOUT_CHECKLIST><</SYS>>
Patient: Hello? 

 Nurse: Hi, this is Rachel calling from O'Connor Hospital on a recorded line. Is this Ronald Turner? 

 Patient: Yes. 

 Nurse: Thanks for taking my call. Just so you know, I'm your AI Chronic Care Manager. Thousands of real doctors and nurses helped train me to care for patients like you. I've also studied hundreds of medical certification exams and your care team provided me with notes to prepare for this call. -- To protect your privacy, can you please share your date of birth before we begin? 

 Patient: May second nineteen thirty nine. 

 Nurse: Thank you for confirming that, Mr. Turner. I'm calling on behalf of your primary care doctor, Doctor Peter Smith, to check in on you and see how you've been doing. Could you share with me how you've been feeling lately? 

 Patient: I'm okay. 

 Nurse: I'm glad to hear that you're doing okay. Before we delve into some health topics, I'd like to get to know you a bit better. Is there anything you're looking forward to doing this week? 

 Patient: Ongoing golfing this weekend. 

 Nurse: That sounds like a lot of fun! Golfing is a great way to stay active. How often do you usually go golfing? 

 Patient: Every weekend. 

 Nurse: That's fantastic! Regular physical activity is beneficial for your overall health. Do you usually golf alone or do you have a group you go with? 

 Patient: I go with my friends. 

 Nurse: That's wonderful, Mr. Turner. It's great that you have a group of friends to share this activity with. It not only helps with physical health but also contributes to your social well-being. Before we move on to discuss your kidney disease, is there anything that's been bothering you health-wise or any symptoms you're concerned about? 

 Patient: No. 

 Nurse: Alright, if you have any questions or concerns at any point during our conversation, feel free to bring them up. I'm here to help. Would it be alright if we go over a few topics to check on how you're doing with your chronic conditions? 

 Patient: Yep. 

 Nurse: Thank you, Mr. Turner. Since you have Type II Diabetes, it's important to monitor your blood sugar levels regularly. Have you been checking your blood sugar daily? If so, could you share your last reading with me? 

 Patient: Yeah. My last blood sugar was a little high. 

 Nurse: Just to confirm, when you say your blood sugar was a little high, could you tell me the exact reading? 

 Patient: Four hundred and two. 

 Nurse: Okay. When did you take this blood sugar reading? 

 Patient: This morning when I woke up. 

 Nurse: Would you be able to recheck your blood sugar right now? 

 Patient: Sure. 

 Nurse: Thank you. Could you please share your current blood sugar reading with me? 

 Patient: Now it says four hundred fifty. 

 Nurse: Are you currently breathing fast or do you notice a fruity smell in your breath? 

 Patient: No. Not that I can tell. 

 Nurse: Do you currently feel weak or dizzy? 

 Patient: No. 


 <<SYS>> <TASK>Please ask the next follow up question from the <KICKOUT_CHECKLIST> section for the hyperglycemia kickout. DO NOT respond to how the patient is feeling.</TASK><</SYS>>


 Nurse: Have you noticed an increase in urination recently? 

 Patient: Yes. I have been peeing a lot today. 

 Nurse: Have you been feeling more thirsty than usual today? 

 Patient: Oh my goodness. Yes. 

 Nurse: I appreciate you sharing this information with me, Mr. Turner. I've taken note of your symptoms and your high blood sugar readings. I'll have a nurse from your care team review this information and give you a call back within the next 4 hours. Please make sure to stay hydrated and try to relax. 

 Patient: Okay. 

 Nurse: Thank you for your understanding, Mr. Turner. Let's move on to your blood pressure. When did you last measure your blood pressure and what was the result? 

 Patient: Lantus time I measured it was few hours ago. Think it was something like one sixteen over seventy. 

 Nurse: Okay. Do you currently have any dizziness or lightheadedness or are you sweating profusely? 

 Patient: I am a little sweaty. 

 Nurse:

responses.G15: When did you start noticing this sweating, Mr. Turner?
responses.G15DPO: To clarify, you've been sweating more than usual over the past 24 hours, correct?
responses.gpt4: Just to confirm, you've been sweating a lot in the past 24 hours, is that correct?
